PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Mrs. Lucinda Taylor
Address: Laddfield, Sask.
Birthplace: Peterborough, Ont.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1913
Where did you set up housekeeping? At home at Kindersley
Where had you been living before that? At home at Kindersley
For how many people did you prepare meals? Usually 6-8
How far was it to your nearest store? Within walking distance
How often could a visit be made to the store? Twice a month or more
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Sugar, tea, salt, dried fruit, bacon, rolled oats, canned vegetables in winter, yeast cakes

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Royal Household
In what quantities did you buy it? About 50 pounds
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.25
How much did you use graham flour? Not used for anything
Whole wheat flour? None
Was flour milled locally? Yes, how far away? 14 miles, what year? 1915
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $2
What other grain products did you use? Rolled oats monthly
Cornmeal? None
Whole Wheat? None
Farina? None
Other? None
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? During the depression 1930 to 1937
How did you grind it? Ordinary flour grinder

During the depression years in Canada, we could often find fresh vegetables and fruit at lower prices than today. We bought fresh vegetables from our own garden and canned them for storage. We also bought canned goods such as applesauce, peaches, and tomatoes. These were cheaper than buying fresh produce.

We also bought eggs from local farms and used them to make cakes and pies. The eggs were fresher and cheaper than store-bought eggs.

In addition to these items, we also bought flour, sugar, and other staples from local stores. These items were cheaper than buying them online or at the supermarket.

Overall, during the Depression years, we were able to save money by buying fresh produce and using it to make our own meals. This helped us to stretch our food budget and save money.
During 1914 after the drought hit and crop failure we had been convinced a little over a year ago that to obtain employment in the South Bank mining town was our best chance. We moved about three miles west where we bought a small farm from Mr. and Mrs. Johnson. The rancher had come in when Mr. and Mrs. Johnson moved away. He went on a trip for a year and he showed me a list that they used for a yearly supply. I don't think I had it for the records. The building used a pack of chickens there were three eggs cream milk until a child fruit they grew an abundance of potatoes or vegetables. We had fruits and games made our own ice cream.

The rancher was from the northern states he taught me to fry chicken southern style, to cook several potatoes and hominy, the largest one to make good coffee, fajitas, tacos and fried potatoes. They used straw dough before I had gone there. The next one wrote was so good they could not get it. People came and went out of nearly all countries. No cold but they made every week end for light rainy coyote games.

They dug up old bacon and out of the animals each week the thieves lived mostly on beans. The ranchers never drank them, always coffee. He told me even if I was alone on the ranch and a stranger walked up if it was noon meal time he would feel his horse and come and eat. The paid if were any remuneration ranch land. The R.R. M.P. always claimed and the rancher under he paroled the river county always on horseback. When Rancher visited each other they stayed for several days you could in a corner usually find chickens and any tobacco that you had in storage Rancher claimed and home stake coming in and were never an exception. It was to the rancher. Rancher loved much better than homesteaders.
During 1914 after the drought hit and crops failed we had been employed to make a living. We got work on a ranch about five miles from town. The owner was a man who had come to the south from Illinois. He had come to Texas looking for work and found it here. He had heard about the good weather and the opportunity for work. He came to Texas in search of a better life.

The rancher had come when maple syrup was yearly surplus. He had heard that there was plenty of work available at the ranch. There was a large house and the buildings were in good condition. There were plenty of trees and plenty of water. They grew an abundance of vegetables and fruit. We had plenty of room to make our own ice cream.

The rancher was from the north and liked the living. He liked to fry chicken something style, to cook several potatoes and hominy. He taught me how to make good coffee, flapjacks and fried potatoes. They said straw dough before I had gone there. They said one winter was so cool they could not get the people enough snow.

I mainly sell vegetables. No doubt they made my wishes out for buying eggs. They dug up old bones and out of the animals.

They lived mostly on beans. The rancher always cooked beans. He said if he was alone on the ranch and on his own he would have more meat. He said it was to feel his home and come and eat. The rancher was an excellent rancher. He paid all the men equally and fairly. When Rancher visited each other they always stayed at the ranch when he paid all the men equally.

And any business that you deal in relaying Rancher always and every time coming in and never ever an exception. Rancher was much better than homesteading.
